Dialogue with People of Other Religions: Its Legitimacy, Conditions, and Etiquette

Prepared by Dr. Ahmed bin Saif Al-Din Turkistani
Associate Professor, Department of Media
College of Da'wah and Media - Imam University

In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful

Preface

Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the Master of Prophets and Messengers, our Prophet Muhammad, and upon his family and companions all together. To proceed:

One could term this era the era of cultural convergence, coexistence, and dialogue. What Professor Marshall McLuhan predicted about forty years ago has largely come true, as the technological push has moved forward faster than what was in the mind of that pioneering media theorist. Who would have imagined a few decades ago that the World Wide Web (the Internet) could connect the world in this manner, whether by transmitting information instantly or by allowing dialogue across the globe with complete freedom and minimal costs—often merely nominal?! This is in addition to the progress that has occurred in other means of communication, the ease of travel and transportation, trade exchange, and other means that provide countless opportunities for meetings between peoples and learning about various cultures and civilizations.

text: The recession of the Cold War and the end of the old international political polarization came to provide cultural and intellectual opportunities that could reduce the scourges of fanaticism, lying in wait for the other, and the insistence on intellectual invasion. It has become more possible than before to spread ideas naturally without—mostly—parties and states standing behind them, but rather unorganized and not well-funded groups exerting their effort to spread their ideas quietly without the historically known obstacles. This situation is closer to achieving peaceful cultural coexistence and civilizational exchange that opens opportunities for all parties. This matter invites us to consider how to benefit from these available opportunities in dialogue and presenting opinions away from coercion and compulsion. It also leads us to the status of dialogue with the "other" in our Islamic religion and our long heritage.

text:
Definition of Dialogue (Hiwar)

Dialogue in the language: The exchange of speech back and forth. In Lisan Al-Arab: (They engage in *Hiwar*, meaning: they exchange speech back and forth. And *Muhawarah*: The exchange of logic and speech in address).

As for Debate/Argument (*Jadal*): Ibn Faris said: (The [letters] Jim, Dal, and Lam form a single root, which pertains to the strengthening of a thing, involving persistence, extension of dispute, and exchanging speech).

Dialogue in terminology: It is the same linguistic meaning mentioned above. It is thus: An exchange of speech between two or more parties without the necessity of hostility between them.

As for Debate (*Jadal*): It is: (The manifestation by disputants of the implications of their views regarding mutual repulsion and negation through words or what stands in their place such as signs and indications).

Scholars distinguish between dialogue and debate, as debate is a likely place for fanaticism, persistence in supporting an opinion whether right or wrong, and arbitrariness in presenting doubts and suspicions about the truth if it emerges from the other direction.
There are terms similar to dialogue (*Hiwar*) and debate (*Jadal*), including: Argumentation (*Muhajjah*), Disputation (*Munazarah*), Discussion (*Munaqashah*), and Research/Inquiry (*Mubahathah*).

Dialogue is constituted merely by recognizing the viewpoints of others, contemplating them, evaluating them, and commenting on them. From this understanding, dialogue can be applied to the cross-pollination of cultures with one another and what results from that in terms of the meeting of interlocutors, mutual correction, and mutual influence.

text:
Definition of Religion (Deen)

Religion is defined as obedience, submission, and establishing a methodology of life based on supreme ideals to which a human adheres. Muhammad Farid Wajdi says in defining religion that it is: "A name for everything by which God is worshipped, and the creed (Milla), and likewise 'Diyana'. The plural of 'Deen' is 'Adyan' and the plural of 'Diyana' is 'Diyanat'."
In the Global Arabic Encyclopedia: "Deen linguistically: Ownership, rule, and management, from 'Dana-hu Deenan' meaning he owned him, ruled him, governed him, managed him, subjugated him, held him to account, rewarded him, and compensated him; from this is 'Maliki Yawm ad-Deen' meaning the Day of Reckoning and Reward. And in the Hadith 'The intelligent one is he who subjugates (Dana) himself' meaning he governed and controlled it."
In the Arabic Encyclopedia: "The Arabic term 'Deen' comprises various meanings, but they are closely linked. The term is derived from the verb 'Dana' and its root is 'Deen', meaning he humbled, enslaved, and held to account. From it is the Day of 'Deen' which is the Day of 'Recompense' or 'Reward'."
In European languages, the word (Religion) is used to express religion, which is a word of Latin origin (Religio) meaning re-gathering and harvesting, a reference to contemplation, worship, meditation, and acting according to what is extracted from those meditations.

As Allah Almighty said: {And to Him belongs whatever is in the heavens and the earth, and to Him is the religion [due] constantly.} (An-Nahl / 52), and the Almighty said: {So is it other than the religion of Allah they desire, while to Him have submitted [all] those within the heavens and earth, willingly or by compulsion, and to Him they will be returned?} (Al Imran / 83), and the Almighty said: {Say, "Indeed, I have been commanded to worship Allah, [being] sincere to Him in religion."} (Az-Zumar / 11), meaning purifying the following for Allah Almighty in all His commands covering all aspects of life. From the Islamic perspective, religion is considered the supreme value, and customs and cultures must adapt to it, or gain its approval for what they contain of conventions.

text:
Definition of Culture

Culture is the sum of beliefs, values, and rules that members of a society accept and comply with. This is because culture is a force and authority directing the behavior of society, defining for its members their perceptions of themselves and the world around them, and determining for them what they like and dislike, what they desire and what they avert from, such as the type of food they eat, the type of clothes they wear, the way they speak, the sports they practice, the historical heroes immortalized in their consciences, the symbols they adopt to express their inner selves, and so on.

From this definition, it becomes clear that culture:
1- Has cumulative growth over the long term: Meaning that culture is not ready-made sciences or knowledge that society can obtain, absorb, and assimilate in a short time, but rather it accumulates over long stages of time.
2- Is transmitted from generation to generation through socialization: The culture of society is transmitted to its new members through socialization, where children acquire the general taste of society during their growth stages.
3- Is of a collective nature: Meaning it is not a private characteristic of the individual but of the group, where the individual shares it with the rest of the members of his society, and it represents the bond that connects all its members.

text: Thus, the culture of a people distinguishes their lifestyle from the lifestyles of other peoples, but it does not isolate them nor necessarily lead them to a state of conflict with other cultures. Within every culture, there may exist those who call for isolation and cutting off from others, or worse, for arrogance, self-aggrandizement, and contempt for others. This may reach the stage of hostility towards others and posing a threat to their existence. Therefore, dialogue was essential to alleviate the intensity of this hostility and enable people of different cultures to coexist and understand one another.

text:
The Goal of Dialogue

The intention of dialogue is not confrontation and silencing the opponent, as that falls under debate and attempting to prevail over the opponent and rendering them unable to respond. Rather, the intention is to achieve all or some of the following:
1- Knowing the propositions of the other party, their points of view, and arguments regarding the issues that are the subject of the dialogue.
2- Informing the other party of information, points of view, and proofs that are absent from them or confusing to them regarding the issues that are the subject of the dialogue.
3- Working to persuade the other party to abandon their points of view and positions, totally or partially, regarding the issues that are the subject of the dialogue, so they may accept and work to adopt them after being convinced, whether immediately after the dialogue or gradually over the long term.
4- Working to explore what the other party possesses of truths and positives, acknowledging them, accepting them, and benefiting from them, as long as (Wisdom is the lost property of the believer; wherever he finds it, he is most deserving of it).
5- Working to explore incorrect or inaccurate information held by the interlocutor and the gaps and errors in their points of view or positions, and working to rectify and correct them.
6- Building a bridge for constructive peaceful communication and blocking the road to confrontations and clashes which dissipate efforts.

The Holy Quran and the Dialogue of Cultures

The Holy Quran has clarified in numerous verses that the multiplicity of human cultures and people's differences in religion is a matter of creation's purpose. The Almighty said: {And if your Lord had willed, He could have made mankind one community; but they will not cease to differ. Except whom your Lord has given mercy, and for that He created them.} [Hud: 118-119]. So difference is a predestined matter just as it is an intended matter so that the proof may be established against the dissenter, but not for fighting and conflict, for disbelief (Kufr) in itself is not a permissible reason to kill a disbeliever or take his life.
As for diversity in races, ethnicities, colors, and languages, it is intended for mutual acquaintance and closeness, not repulsion and division. Allah Almighty said: {And We made you into nations and tribes that you may know one another.} [Al-Hujurat: 13]. Thus, the intent of cultural plurality and diversity at its lowest levels is meeting, acquaintance, and the exchange of ideas and experiences developed by different lifestyles. This increases the depth of each culture's components through what it generates from other cultures.
Through continuous peaceful contact between cultures, human individuals learn to reduce their biases and soften their negative feelings towards owners of other cultures. Thus, tolerance increases among humans, and those erroneous ideas towards...

How often does one of us hold a negative idea about another individual where the sole motive is the lack of dialogue with this other and lack of close, documented, sure knowledge of them? But soon the haze of that bias clears as soon as dialogue and close acquaintance take place with them.

In the Holy Quran, there are many verses confirming the diversity of human experiences and [commanding] not to despise others merely for differing from them. Islamic culture has become rich due to contact with other peoples, exchanging ideas with them, and taking what they have of truth, even if that truth comes from those who are hostile to Islam. Muslim peoples accepted the creed of Islam and retained their own customs and traditions that do not contradict Islam, even if they do not agree with the customs and traditions of other Islamic peoples. That is the breadth of Islam and its tolerance which encompassed everyone.
Perhaps the best that can be extracted from this is that diversity in dialogue is a tool for fertility and enrichment, as expressed by the social thinker Scott Peck when he said: "The overall mission of human communication and dialogue boils down to (or should boil down to) reaching reconciliation... Efficient communication and dialogue can ultimately achieve the removal of walls and barriers that lead to misunderstanding which distances humans from one another."

And as He, Glory be to Him, said: {Invite to the way of your Lord with wisdom and good instruction} [An-Nahl: 125]. And the Almighty said: {And do not insult those they invoke other than Allah, lest they insult Allah in enmity without knowledge} [Al-An'am: 108]. Mere roughness in dialogue and using dry, rude vocabulary is undesirable, let alone insulting people, harming them, belittling them, and despising them, and other practices stemming primarily from lack of recognition of others and lack of belief in the utility of dialogue itself. Such people should not undertake dialogue, nor can they achieve any positive results from it.

text:
Doubts Regarding the Utility of Dialogue

There are some doubts regarding the utility and benefit of dialogue, especially in interfaith dialogue. These doubts revolve around some arguments that require us to clarify them and how to respond to them in a way that proves the importance of the principle of dialogue without applying it at every moment and with everyone. Among these arguments:

1- That dialogue might lead to confusion and disturbance, due to the resulting unpraiseworthy intellectual influence. For example, in the case of dialogue between Muslims and Christians: some Muslims fear that Christian discourse might lead to introducing some doubts and intellectual confusion into the minds of Muslims, causing some of their concepts to become disturbed due to that confusion.
This statement is true if the interlocutor has little knowledge of the subject of dialogue, or has weak arguments and is unable to clarify and explain. But if he is qualified for dialogue, fortified with knowledge, proof, and good adherence to his religion, then dialogue increases him in solidity, strength, and in revealing the falsehood of the other party and refuting their doubts.

book_title: Dialogue with People of Other Religions: Its Legitimacy, Conditions, and Etiquette
publisher: The book is published on the Saudi Ministry of Endowments website without data
text:
2- That dialogue might lead to more fanaticism and hardening of positions on both sides. In the case of interfaith dialogue, the dialogue is usually between fundamental premises and holistic concepts of existence, divinity, and laws. These are concepts of such strength and rootedness that dialogue does not affect them, and the inevitable result is that things remain as they were, or become more intense than they were.
To respond to this, it suffices to mention the clear truth as was the case in most dialogues of the Holy Quran, where the messengers of Allah, peace be upon them, debated their people regarding establishing the Lordship of Allah Almighty, His Divinity, and establishing the Resurrection and Recompense. There is no harm in a dialogue established on these major foundations to proceed from them to what is below them. As for the saying that all position-holders will harden in their stance, it can be said that some interfaith dialogues resulted in major shifts in belief from which Islam gained much, past and present, as it is the religion gaining most from this door, alongside what it achieves in clarifying its position and explaining its creeds, thereby repelling ambiguity and repelling or lessening hostility.

3- That dialogue leads to Fitnah (strife) and clash: This argument is based on the rule of blocking the means (Sadd al-Dhara'i) and erecting barriers, but it may be exaggerated until barriers are erected with others and the Islamic truth remains absent. Dialogue not disciplined by the conditions and etiquette of dialogue may turn into strife and clash, but not every dialogue is destined for that outcome certainly, as long as there is adherence to the conditions of correct dialogue free from futile argumentation or non-adherence to dialogue etiquette, as will be explained later.

4- That dialogue gives an opportunity to polish false opinions: There is a generalization in this statement that is not correct in every case. Mostly, false opinions only acquire their luster if they isolate themselves with the atmosphere and lights, far from being objected to and confronted through dialogue. Dialogue provides the opportunity to weaken false opinions and lower the degree of their glow and luster, through the truth it reveals that contradicts them and the falsehood implied within them.

5- That dialogue might lead to compromising principles, manipulating them, and mixing them with others to reach middle positions for mutual satisfaction, or claiming the relativity of truth and that facts and opinions, however they differ and conflict, are all correct. The truth is that this caution is valid whenever the clarity of principle and the justice of their cause is absent from the interlocutor on the Islamic side, otherwise, they would be a failed lawyer. Eagerness for dialogue from competent people is the safety valve against falling into this deep abyss. The interlocutor must know that compromising principles and mixing Islam with others in its principles and beliefs is not a goal of dialogue, so that the interlocutor does not make it an illusory goal for achievement.

6- That dialogue might land the people of truth in pitfalls and embarrassments: This happens if they do not perform their role well, and thus the people of false opinion win due to their better preparation and better use of logic. In that, there is creating doubt for the people of truth regarding their truth. This result is possible to occur. But the reason for its occurrence is the scientific weakness of the interlocutors or their negligence in preparation, not the dialogue itself.

text:
Clash of Civilizations

Some Western theorists have formulated theories about the futility of dialogue between civilizations and cultures, concluding that positive dialogue between civilizations has ended with their evolution into the form of the current Western liberal civilization, and no hope or benefit remains for dialogue. This is what Francis Fukuyama, the author of the "End of History" theory in its current form, posited.
If Fukuyama concluded that evolution in the line of human history culminated in the victory of liberalism and the defeat of socialism, then Samuel Huntington, author of the "Clash of Civilizations" theory, claims that the most violent battles of history are those that have not yet occurred. And that they will not be on the level of nation-states nor on the level of ideological axes, but will evolve to a higher level, which is the level of human civilizations, the widest cultural entity to which a human belongs.
The unit of analysis for him is civilization. Although he admits that the civilizational factor is a highly complex factor, he claims nonetheless that he has mastered it - but a mere fleeting look at his definition of civilization confirms that he has not reached a precise definition of that concept.

book_title: Dialogue with People of Other Religions: Its Legitimacy, Conditions, and Etiquette
publisher: The book is published on the Saudi Ministry of Endowments website without data
text:
Civilization, according to Huntington, is a "cultural identity". This is his definition of it, and when he realizes that it is a gelatinous definition, and very far from being a comprehensive and exclusive definition - as logicians say - he turns towards more explanation and clarification. He tells us that cultural identity overlaps and falls under larger affiliations: "The culture of a village in southern Italy may differ from the culture of a village in northern Italy, but both villages inevitably share the characteristics of the overarching Italian national culture, and this overarching culture is what distinguishes all Italian villages from German villages, for example. But that does not prevent all European villages from gathering under the umbrella of a wider culture, which is what is called European culture, which is the culture that distinguishes all European villages from Arab or Asian villages."
This last cultural level is what Huntington means by civilization, and it is a loose definition, because its author soon enters into confusion and contradicts what he previously established.

text:
Issues in Which Dialogue is Not Permissible

If we are convinced of the legitimacy of dialogue and its apparent benefit, we should look at it as being legitimate within its limits and utility. Dialogue is not absolutely legitimate to cover every matter; it is not a kind of intellectual luxury, curiosity, love of exploration, or splitting hairs in arguments. There are specific issues into which it is not permissible to delve through dialogue or debate, either due to the limitation of the human mind regarding them, or due to the lack of any scientific or practical fruit resulting from them, or because they are fundamentally settled by a legislative text or consensus.

text: Delving into research on the Essence (Zat) of Allah Almighty, for example, is religiously forbidden. This is not a field for research, debate, or dialogue, because speaking on that majestic matter is delving without knowledge, and knowledge is a primary condition for entering into dialogue, a condition absent in this case. It falls under what Allah forbade in His saying: {And do not pursue that of which you have no knowledge. Indeed, the hearing, the sight and the heart - about all those [one] will be questioned.} [Al-Isra: 36]. There are many issues upon which no practical ruling is based, such as most of the issues delved into by those called Muslim philosophers like Al-Farabi, Ibn Rushd, and Ibn Sina, and many Sufis like Ibn Arabi, Ibn Sab'in, Al-Suhrawardi, and others. Among the issues in which debate is forbidden is everything in which Allah and His Messenger have ruled with a clear, decisive text or upon which there is consensus (Ijma) of Islamic scholars. Indeed, everything about which speaking is religiously forbidden is absolutely impermissible for dialogue, just as debating its matter is impermissible. Thus, definitive rulings in religion are not a locus for dialogue or debate for the sake of reconsidering, evaluating, or changing them.

text: Qualifications of the Muslim Dialoguer: The Muslim dialoguer may engage in dialogue with various fronts, whether with Muslims like himself, or with innovating Muslims, or extremists, or negligent ones, or those intellectually defeated before Western propositions and inclined to interpret religion to align with those propositions, or the Muslim may converse with some of the People of the Book or those with no religion. The motives of those the Muslim meets in dialogue vary; some have good intentions in seeking the truth and readiness to accept it when it becomes clear, and some use dialogue as a way to present and spread their views while insisting on not accepting the truth if it comes from another party, even if it becomes clearly evident. The Muslim dialoguer must know the backgrounds of those he converses with well so he can harness his knowledge and talents in a way ensuring he deals with each of these groups appropriately. The following is a presentation of some necessary qualifications for the Muslim dialoguer:

This requires knowledge of Tafsir (exegesis) of its types, and expertise in the noble Prophetic Hadith and the basic sciences of Sharia. If complete encompassment of all that is impossible, it is obligatory that a person does not dialogue or argue except in what he knows with certain knowledge regarding matters of Sharia and religious sciences. It is part of the perfection of the jurist's jurisprudence and the scholar's knowledge that he knows his own worth, does not exceed it, verifies his scientific field so as not to exit it, and does not address what he is not qualified for.

text: 8- Methodizing thoughts: Learning requires intelligence, perseverance, diligence, and insight, whereas methodizing thoughts requires a special skill honed by practice and training. Many scholars, no matter how much their harvest of knowledge based on evidence increases, may not be good at arranging its issues in a logical order, so their knowledge appears scattered and mixed with one another. The more their outcome of knowledge increases, the more their minds become mixed and confused, and they transfer that mixture and confusion to the listener. This is the last thing the listener needs and the first thing that spoils the scholar's message and causes his failure in dialogue. The successful dialoguer is the one who trains himself to methodize thoughts, arrange texts and evidences, and extract premises subject to analysis for the purpose of extracting results from them. Giving results without that logical arrangement may not be a subject of conviction or acceptance by the other party in the dialogue nor by the audience of listeners.

Everyone who dialogues must prepare himself to accept the result of the dialogue if the weakness of his opinion and argument appears against the strength of the opponent's opinion and argument. Much of the stubbornness that follows dialogue traces its origin to the dialoguer himself not possessing the humility to compel his self to accept the truth. text: Etiquettes of Dialogue: Once the Muslim dialoguer is qualified to engage in dialogue so that he reaps its fruits and benefits himself and his religion from it, he must adopt the etiquettes of dialogue and adhere to its standards by which the highest benefit is achieved. Among the most important of these etiquettes are: 1- Adhering to the subject of dialogue and not deviating from it. This is a methodological and organizational issue of utmost importance. Failure to adhere to it leads to mixing issues with one another, which leads to none of them maturing through research, questioning, comparison, evaluation, and deduction. This aspect can be addressed by setting the priorities of the dialogue well, and establishing an arbitration body to control the interlocutors whenever they tend to deviate from the framework of the subject. 2- The necessity of defining the terms used in the dialogue and explaining their implications well, because a single term may mean something different to both parties. Here, the speaker must declare what he means specifically by the main term his speech revolves around during the dialogue. 3- Discussing issues according to their importance. It is not proper etiquette of dialogue to amplify branch issues at the expense of original issues, for many branch issues are resolved automatically as soon as their major fundamentals and the source of difference regarding them are discussed.

Whatever the result of the dialogue, the Muslim is tasked with listening to comfort the mind of the speaker, and that is more conducive to bringing him to the side of truth. That is what the Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) did in this situation, and in every dialogue situation he had with disbelievers and dissenters. If even the disbeliever is granted that opportunity to be listened to so he can present his ideas and opinions, then that same right must be given to dissenters within the framework of the general Islamic conception, or to dissenters from among the people of cultures, civilizations, and scriptural religions in particular. Dialogue is an important mechanism for achieving the performance of the duty of Da'wah (Call) by conveying the message of the true religion. Therefore, the Holy Quran cited numerous examples of it and called for its use conditioned by the etiquettes of dialogue.
